Currency headwinds weighed on results.U.S. comps grew 6.4%, while international comps rose 7.9%.Shares nearly 10%, slicing below their 50-day line. Pizza rival Papa John's (PZZA) lost 2.7%, and Pizza Hut parent Yum Brands (YUM) fell 1.3%.Dunkin' Brands' (DNKN) per-share earnings rose 10% to 44 cents, beating by a penny, on 2% revenue growth to $189.8 million, edging above views for $188 million.Demands for breakfast sandwiches and beverages fueled 2% in same-store sales growth at U.S. Dunkin' Donuts, above analyst estimates. Baskin-Robbins' domestic comps rose 5%."As (Q1 same-store sales) results for the Dunkin' U.S. segment were ahead of our expectations, we continue to believe sustained SSS trends is likely" through 2016 and 2017, wrote Palmer in a separate report.Dunkin' reaffirmed full-year guidance for 4%-6% revenue growth and $2.20-$2.22 in per-share profit.Amid the success of Starbucks' (SBUX) mobile-order-and-pay service, in which customers can order ahead and pick up in store, Dunkin' also announced Thursday the rollout of "on-the-go ordering" for loyalty program members in New York City, starting in just a few weeks. The company had started testing the service in select cities late last year.Dunkin' shares closed down 0.8% as they form a wide cup-with-handle base. Starbucks also lost 0.8%.

Facebook (FB), PayPal (PYPL) and Boeing (BA) report earnings on Wednesday. And with the market digesting Apple’s (AAPL) earnings miss and a Federal Reserve decision on interest rates, it could be an interesting session. Here’s what you need to know:Facebook is expected to report earnings of 62 cents a share on revenue of $5.25 billion, both up 48% from last year, when it issues results after the close. Investors will pay close attention to the social networking giant’s ad revenue growth and its number of monthly active users, which jumped 14% to 1.6 billion last quarter. They'll also want any clues about Facebook engagement amid reports that users are posting less and that younger people trend toward Snapchat.Shares breached support at the 50-day line Tuesday after finding support there the prior two sessions. The stock is now about 7% below a cup-with-handle buy point at 117.09.PayPal also reports after the close. Analysts project that earnings will grow 20% to 35 cents a share while revenue rises 19%to $2.5 billion. PayPal is working with Facebook, Starbucks (SBUX) and other big brands to help make customer transactions more seamless.PayPal stock is trading just below buy range from an alternate entry at 40.03. It’s also trading 6% below its all-time high as it works on a larger consolidation pattern.Boeing reports in the morning. Analysts see EPS falling 7.6% to $1.82 and revenue down 3.2% to $21.43 billion. Watch for comments on pricing for its commercial jets as low fuel prices allow airlines to fly older planes and seek discounts on new ones.Boeing stock is trading 11% below its 52-week high and hasn’t closed above its 200-day line this year.A two-day Fed meeting ends tomorrow. The widespread expectation is for rates to remain unchanged for now, but Fed-watchers will pay close attention for clues about when the next rate hike may be.Apple's disappointing Q2 earnings report after the close Tuesday is likely to have a negative impact on the market. The consumer tech giant's EPS fell 19% to $1.90 while revenue dropped 13% to $50.6 billion. Both missed Wall Street views, and so did Apple's Q3 revenue outlook.Apple shares fell 8% in late trading Tuesday, with iPhone chip suppliers also selling off.

Tesla Motors (TSLA) got a price target raise despite missing Q1 delivery figures. Analysts were dived on Palo Alto Networks (PANW)  Tuesday while Ruckus Wireless (RKUS) and Cisco Systems (CSCO) were downgraded. Starbucks (SBUX) nabbed a buy as coverage was started on a plateful of restaurants by Evercore ISI Group.Credit Suisse took Tesla's PT to 280 from 240 while keeping an outperform on the luxury car maker as preorders soar for its $35,000 Model 3, even though Q1 deliveries fell short of estimates.Tesla shares down 2% in the morning, closed up 3.4% to 255.47.Meanwhile, Bank of America downgraded Cisco to neutral. Needham upped its PT on cybersecurity firm Palo Alto Networks to 187 from 171, a day after Palo Alto's analyst day. But Goldman Sachs trimmed Palo Alto's PT to 188 from 191. Cisco lost 2%, and Palo Alto fell 6% to 151.92.Ruckus Wireless got five downgrades from analysts early Tuesday following Brocade Communications Systems' (BRCD) announcement on Monday that it agreed to buy the wireless firm for $1.2 billion. Brocade shares were up 4.2% Tuesday after sinking 13.6% Monday. Ruckus was up 1.7%, adding to its 32% spike Monday.Needham and Stifel Nicolaus cut their ratings on Ruckus from buy to hold while RBC Capital's went from outperform to sector perform. Macquarie cut its rating to neutral and William Blair's dropped to market perform.Evercore ISI Group started coverage on a bevy of restaurants, but only two with buy ratings: Starbucks and Wendy's (WEN).Starbucks shares were down 0.35%, while Wendy's edged up 1%.It put a hold on Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), McDonald's (MCD), Yum Brands (YUM), Domino's Pizza (DPZ), Panera Bread (PNRA) and Jack in the Box (JACK) and a sell on Dunkin Brands (DNKN).

The flagship utilities ETF fell 2.1% in massive volume Thursday, triggering a sell signal as it crashed through its 50-day moving average.XLU was a best-performing exchange traded fund in the first quarter, jumping 15.5%. It hit its stride as investors favored defensive plays amid extreme market volatility. That momentum helped it earn a spot for a while on IBD Leaderboard, the first-ever ETF to do so.Meanwhile, on one of the biggest days for earnings season so far, four ETFs on investors' watch lists closed modestly lower.Each of these exchange traded fund invests in two or more of these five highly rated industry leaders that reported Thursday: Alphabet (GOOGL), Microsoft (MSFT), Starbucks (SBUX), Under Armour (UA) and Visa (V).Several of those big-name stocks fell after hours on quarterly misses.Major indexes struggled for gains Thursday amid mixed news on unemployment and manufacturing.SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) added 0.4% while closing in the bottom half of the day's range.Market Vectors Junior Gold Miners (GDXJ) popped 1.8% on the stock market today. Its No. 3 stock holding United Airlines (UAL) tumbled 10% after forecasting weak passenger revenue forecast in its earnings report Wednesday.Its No. 1 holding Southwest Airlines (LUV) and No. 9 holding Alaska Air (ALK) traded mixed despite strong Q1 reports Thursday that were underpinned by lower fuel prices.Here's a look at how the major exchange traded funds tracking various asset classes are performing today.Following daily ETF market action can be key to successful investing:SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), -0.5%, RS 62PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), 0%, RS 58SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA), -0.6%, RS 65IShares Core S&P Mid-Cap (IJH), -0.9%, RS 65IShares Russell 2000 (IWM), -0.5%, RS 50IShares MSCI EAFE (EFA), -0.6%, RS 45Vanguard FTSE Emerging Markets (VWO), -1.1%, RS 50SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), +0.4%, RS 76IShares Core U.S. Aggregate Bond (AGG), -0.1%, RS 45PowerShares DB U.S.$ Bullish (UUP), 0%, RS 28IPath S&P 500 VIX Short-Term Futures (VXX), +1.9%, RS 9

Facebook (FB), Starbucks (SBUX) and Visa (V) are among stocks that would hold up well if the U.S. economy goes into recession, a Goldman Sachs report said.Although Goldman didn't say it's looking for a recession, and many economists say recession is still a remote possibility, the list comes amid recent red flags that some analysts have said could augur recession.Railroad shipments -- a forward-looking indicator -- have fallen amid unstable economic conditions. Industrial production has also been weak, and the strong dollar has hit exporters.David Kostin, Goldman Sachs' chief U.S. equity analyst, came up with the recommendations for recession stocks on the assumption that strong balance sheets and high domestics sales should outperform in a downturn, according to Bloomberg.In addition to Facebook, Starbucks and Visa, Goldman also named Alphabet (GOOGL,), Whole Foods Market (WFM), which continues to benefit from the trend in the U.S. toward healthy food, industrial giant 3M (MMM) and Verizon Communications (VZ), the top wireless service provider.Facebook closed up 0.3% on the stock market today. Starbucks rose 1.5%, Visa ticked 0.2% higher, and Alphabet rose less than 0.1%. Whole Foods ended up 0.9%, while 3M surged 5.2% after reporting strong earnings Tuesday.Verizon last Thursday reported that Q4 EPS shot up 25%  to 89 cents on a 3.2% rise in revenue to $34.25 billion, both topping estimates. Shares gained 2.6% Tuesday.Facebook reports Wednesday, and consensus of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for earnings per share to rise 26% to 68 cents a share on a 40% jump in revenue to $5.37 billion.Visa will report Thursday, and analysts see EPS up 8% to 68 cents on a 7% hike in revenue to $3.62 billion.Chipotle (CMG), Marathon Petroleum (MRO) and Michael Kors (KORS) made it on Goldman's list despite coming under major pressure recently.Chipotle's sales and stock have plunged since an E. coli outbreak at some locations. Marathon has sold off along with the rest of the energy sector as oil prices sank. And Michael Kors has been in an extended slide amid a shift in consumer tastes.On Tuesday, Chipotle shares rose 1.35%, Marathon rallied 3.8%, and Michael Kors rose climbed 2.9%.

Microsoft (MSFT) received a pair of price target cuts Friday following a disappointing quarterly report, while Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) also had its price target lowered and Starbucks (SBUX) got a higher price target.BMO Capital Markets lowered its price target on Microsoft to 57 from 58 and Morgan Stanley lowered it to 64 from 66. Late Thursday, the Redmond, Wash.-based tech giant fell short of fiscal third-quarter sales and earnings views and also offered disappointing sales guidance.Microsoft shares closed down 7.2% on the stock market today.Alphabet’s stock price retreated 5.4% following a disappointing quarter of its own. On Thursday, the company missed Wall Street expectations on the top and bottom lines.Alphabet’s price target was cut to 888 from 930 at Stifel, to 850 from 900 at Morgan Stanley, and to 825 from 910 at Needham.Starbucks’ price target was raised to 72 from 69 by Goldman Sachs, which maintained its buy rating on the stock.Even so, the coffee king’s stock price fell 4.9% Friday following the previous day’s disappointing fiscal Q2 report, which included a revenue miss and a weak full-year forecast.Shares of Under Armour (UA) edged up 0.1% after its price target was raised to 53 from 50 by Telsey Advisory Group. The performance apparel company beat quarterly earnings views Thursday.General Motors (GM) fell 1.5% after its price target was raised to 34 from 30 at RBC Capital Markets, which rates the stock a sector perform.On Thursday, the car maker beat Q1 earnings estimates, driven by strong results in the U.S and China and an improved performance in Europe.Taco Bell parent Yum Brands (YUM) had its price target hiked to 94 from 90 at RBC Capital Markets, which maintained its outperform rating on the stock. Shares fell 0.6%.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Stocks closed slightly lower Friday, but the major market indexes still wrapped up the week with gains of nearly 2% each.The Nasdaq and Dow Jones industrial average gave up 0.2% each, while the S&P 500 slipped 0.1%. Volume was mixed, slightly higher on the NYSE but lower on the Nasdaq vs. Thursday's total, according to preliminary figures. Winners outpaced losers by about a 5-4 margin on the NYSE and by 7-5 on the Nasdaq.Energy, investment banks and computer-related stocks led the downside in today's stock market action. Oil stocks were weighed down by a 3% slide in West Texas intermediate crude prices to $40.36 a barrel, ahead of an oil production meeting this weekend in Doha, Qatar.Super Micro Computer (SMCI) gapped down and sank 20%, slicing its 200-day moving average in hefty trade. Shares are now well below a 33.89 buy point initially cleared March 30. The maker of server systems and other computer gear guided fiscal Q3 earnings lower. It reports April 28 after the close.Apple (AAPL) provided the biggest drag on the Dow, shedding 2% to close back below the 200-day moving average, which it had regained Wednesday. Volume ran about 22% higher than usual. The iPad maker will continue with lowered iPhone production in the April to June quarter, according to the Nikkei Asian Review.Citigroup (C) rose as much as 3.5% intraday but pared its gains to close slightly lower. The big bank reported Q1 earnings that fell less than expected. Shares are 9% above their 50-day line but 9% below the 200-day line.Gold miners, utilities and apparel retailers bucked the downtrend. Among utilities, Aqua America (WTR) rose 2% to reclaim its 50-day moving average. It's been trading mostly in flat-base range since early February.INC Research (INCR) led the IBD 50 with a near 2% gain in above-average volume to extend its win streak for a fifth straight session. The stock is just shy of a 50.50 cup-base buy point. The company provides clinical development services to the biopharmaceutical and medical device industries.Economic news was mixed. Industrial production fell 0.6% in March, well below projections for a 0.1% slip. The New York Fed Empire State Manufacturing Survey for April jumped to 9.6, soaring past economists' forecasts for 3.0. April consumer sentiment fell to 89.7, vs. 91 in March and views for an uptick to 91.8.Reports out Monday include the housing market index for April. The Fed's William Dudley, Neel Kashkari and Eric Rosengren are also scheduled to speak.American Express (AXP), Coca-Cola (KO), Alphabet (GOOGL), McDonald's (MCD) and Starbucks (SBUX) are among companies reporting next week as earnings season ramps up.Image provided by Shutterstock.

There's more than meets the eye to California Gov. Jerry Brown's plan to hike the state minimum wage to $15 an hour — about $3.50 more.Including nonwage costs — payroll taxes, paid sick leave and ObamaCare's employer mandate — minimum compensation for a full-time worker could rise as high as $18.52 an hour by 2022, an IBD analysis finds.Social insurance taxes would add $1.15 an hour to the $15 wage. Three days of paid sick leave now on the books in California would add another 19 cents. And the ObamaCare after-tax fine, now $2,160 per uncovered full-time worker and rising each year, will equate to roughly $2.18 an hour in pretax wages. Adding in workers' compensation insurance and unemployment insurance would push the total close to $19 an hour.One big change from a $15 minimum wage has flown below the radar: Many low-wage workers would no longer qualify for Medicaid. For example, a single mom with one child who worked 32 hours per week would earn more than the 138% of poverty cutoff for expanded Medicaid under ObamaCare, though her child would still qualify. A single adult who works just three full days a week also would exceed the income threshold.To no small degree, the $15 minimum-wage movement is asking low-wage employers to lift their workers up closer to the middle class and to provide a full menu of social benefits on top. It looks like a recipe for trouble, and even Brown may be wary about it, insisting that the governor retain authority to delay wage hikes if the state sees a fall in employment or retail sales, or if the state faces a budget deficit. Brown had little room for maneuver because a $15 wage initiative that qualified for the November ballot looked like a sure winner and would have provided no flexibility if the wage hike started backfiring.One early-warning sign for California's wage experiment was Wal-Mart's (WMT) announcement in January that it would shutter stores in Oakland and Los Angeles and cancel two planned stores in Washington D.C., dealing a blow to three cities on the leading edge of the push for a much higher minimum wage.Before Los Angeles put its minimum wage on a path to $15 an hour, the question of how city employers would respond to the simultaneous imposition of a health insurance mandate was simply ignored. An analysis of the wage hike's labor cost impact by the Institute for Research on Labor and Employment at the University of California, Berkeley, explicitly excluded health insurance — or a mandate penalty. The authors explained: "Health benefits are excluded since ... the costs of the benefits will not change if wages are increased." The Congressional Budget Office came to a different conclusion, finding that the ObamaCare employer mandate would exacerbate the impact of a minimum-wage hike. It estimated that a minimum-wage hike to $10.10 an hour could cost 500,000 jobs."(The) additional cost on employers for some low-wage workers who do not currently have employment-based health insurance ... further boosts the likelihood that employers' savings from reducing the size of their workforces would exceed their adjustment costs," the CBO said.Those adjustment costs might include adding labor-saving technology.Wendy's (WEN) CFO Todd Penegor explained in an August earnings call, "We continue to look at initiatives and how we work to offset any impacts of future wage inflation through technology initiatives, whether that's customer self-order kiosks (or) whether that's automating more in the back of the house in the restaurant."Starbucks (SBUX) and Yum Brands’ (YUM) Taco Bell are among the restaurant chains promoting mobile ordering, which reduces the need for cashiers. McDonald's (MCD) is about to start testing mobile apps as well.The truth about the ObamaCare employer mandate is that it hasn't been nearly as much of a burden on businesses as feared, so they haven't had to cut workers' hours below 30 per week in a dramatic way. But the reason is hardly cause for celebration: Employers have figured out how to dodge liability by offering "affordable" coverage that costs much more than their modest-wage workers are likely to pay.That's left millions of modest-wage, full-time workers without affordable coverage options. It's possible that California's embrace of a $15 minimum wage will add to their ranks. But the status quo of full-time workers thrown under the bus by ObamaCare may not hold. If the mandate ever becomes something that can't be easily dodged, minimum-wage employers in California will likely cut work hours in a big way, diluting the promise of a living wage.

With stocks on track for their worst January since at least 2009, breakouts have been few and far between. But for a stock to break out, it has to form a base first.Here’s a look at five IBD 50 stocks that are building bases: Facebook (FB), Starbucks (SBUX), Ulta Beauty (ULTA), Foot Locker (FL) and Edwards Lifesciences (EW).Facebook earns a highest-possible IBD Composite Rating of 99. The social networking giant reports quarterly earnings after the close on Wednesday.Shares are trading about 12% below a consolidation buy point of 110.75. Last week, shares were able to find support at the key 200-day line. Facebook rose 0.3% on Tuesday.Starbucks, which has a 96 Composite Rating, also found support at the 200-day line last week. Shares are trading 8% below a 64.10 buy point. Starbucks rose 1.6% Tuesday.Last Thursday, the coffee giant beat quarterly earnings expectations but missed revenue views and issued weak guidance. Still, Starbucks says it’s bullish on its expansion in China.Ulta Beauty reported better-than-expected quarterly results in early December. The beauty products retailer has a 97 Composite Rating.Ulta stock is building a flat base with a 188.58 buy point and is trading 5% below the pivot. Shares are looking to retake the 50-day line in Tuesday’s session. Ulta rose 2%, above its 50-day.Foot Locker is trying to retake its 200-day line, but looks to be hitting resistance there. Shares are trading 14% below a consolidation buy point. They're up 2.6% today.The shoe retailer has a 93 Composite Rating.Edwards Lifesciences has a 94 Composite Rating. When the heart valve maker issues its quarterly results next week, earnings are projected to have risen 17%.Shares were able to retake the 50-day moving average just a few sessions after finding support at the 200-day line. The stock is now just 3% below an 83.53 flat-base buy point. But the stock fell 4 cents to 80.16.O’Reilly Automotive (ORLY), Ross Stores (ROST) and Campbell Soup (CPB) are among other IBD 50 members working on bases.While breakouts provide buying opportunities, the current market environment warrants a cautious outlook.

Stocks futures were positive and ticking higher ahead of Friday's open as a number of stocks and commodities sought to rebound from Thursday's tough day of trade.Dow futures nosed 1.1% above fair market value. S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 futures pushed up 1.2%. Russell 2000 futures showed a 1% gain.The stock market today rolls into Friday's session with the Nasdaq down 2.2%, the S&P 500 down 2.7% and the Russell 2000 toting a 3.2% loss for the week.Early economic news showed retail sales up 0.2% in January, up 0.1% minus autos, the Commerce Department said. Both numbers were in line with expectations. The department also revised December's sales growth upward to 0.2%.The Labor Department reported January export prices slipped 0.8%, import prices dipped 0.2%, vs. December drops of 0.8% and 1,1%, respectively. Economists projected a 1.4% decline in import prices and a 0.6% drop for exports.At 10 a.m. ET, the Commerce Department reports December business inventories, and the University of Michigan delivers its initial estimate on consumer sentiment.Bonds eased. The dollar rose. Crude oil bounced 5% off Thursday's 13-year low. That put West Texas Intermediate near $28 a barrel -- down 11% for the week -- but Friday's early rebound sent energy stocks to many of the top premarket gains among S&P 500 issues.  Baker Hughes (BHI) reports its weekly rig count at 1 p.m.Gold eased 1% to below $1,238 an ounce, about 7% above its week-ago settle. As a group, gold and silver mining stocks were up more than 10% for the week, although Yamana Gold (AUY) and Newmont Mining (NEM) pulled back slightly before Friday's open.Overseas market action was mixed. Europe's markets traded up between 1.5% and 2% near midday. For the week, London's FTSE 100 tacked toward a 3.6% loss. Frankfurt's DAX was down 4.2% and the CAC 40 in Paris swung toward a 5.9% decline.In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 crumbled 4.8% Friday, leaving it down 11.1% for the week. In Hong Kong, which reopened Thursday, the Hang Seng index slipped 1.2% Friday for a 5% drop in its short week. Markets in Shanghai and Shenzhen reopen Monday.Many influential U.S. stocks were bucking for rebounds. JPMorgan (JPM) bounced nearly 4%, Goldman Sachs (GS) jumped 2% to lead the Dow in premarket action. Both banks dived 4%  in heavy trade Thursday.Apple (AAPL) traded a fraction higher after ending Thursday's session with a 0.3% loss this week.  Boeing (BA) marked the Dow's only premarket decline, down 0.4% following its 7% flameout in massive trade on Thursday.Wynn Resorts (WYNN) rolled a 4% gain as its fourth-quarter earnings, reported late Thursday, contracted less than expected by analysts. Revenue fell slightly more than expectations that followed the company's preannounced results. Revenue from Macau declined 27% and from Las Vegas increased 3.8% for the year.Video game leader Activision-Blizzard (ATVI) caved 10% after its late-Thursday report showed Q4 earnings and revenue below consensus projections, as well as weak Q1 guidance. Shares ended Thursday in a test of resistance at their 200-day moving average, 24% below their Dec. 29 high.Four-in-five stocks on the IBD 50 list held flat before the starting bell. Starbucks (SBUX) notched the group's biggest advance, up 1.4%. The stock had narrowed a 3% loss to less than 1% on Thursday, ending the session up 0.8% for the week. Shares are feeling for the bottom of a shallow, four-month consolidation.Ireland-based budget airline Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) ruddered down 2.5% to the bottom of the list.  The stock ended Thursday up more than 4% for the week, vying for its first weekly gain since December. In the process, it retook its 200-day moving average, but in weak trade, hinting at the start of the right side of a seven-week consolidation.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Alphabet (GOOGL), Microsoft (MSFT), Starbucks (SBUX) and Visa (V) were all trading at or near buy points going into their quarterly earnings reports last night. But in what could be seen as a big letdown for investors, all four issued disappointing results and/or guidance, which has sent the stocks tumbling below key levels.Not only is this notable because of their big names, but also because most of them are highly rated by IBD. Alphabet currently earns an IBD Composite Rating of 98 out of 99, while Visa has a 92, and Starbucks has a 90. Microsoft has a Composite Rating of 73, meaning it outperforms 73% of all stocks based on fundamental and technical factors.IBD's Take: How do Alphabet, Microsoft, Starbucks, Visa measure up? Find out at IBD Stock CheckupAlphabet gapped down 5.4% in giant volume, breaching its 50-day line. It’s also triggering a sell signal, with shares now more than 5% below the cup-with-handle buy point at 777.41. The stock is trading 9% below its February high.Microsoft plunged 7.2% in heavy volume, with the stock breaking below the 50-day. Shares are now looking for support at the 200-day line. Microsoft was near its 56.95 buy point in Thursday’s session, but it's now trading 9% below that level.Starbucks is dropping below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages in quick turnover, losing 4.9%. Shares are trading 7% below a saucer-with-handle buy point at 61.74, and 10% below their October peak.And Visa is now below its 10-day line, falling 2.1% in fast trade. It’s still holding above the 50-day and 200-day lines, which recently crossed in a bullish manner. Shares are now 3% below their cup-base buy point at 81.11.Whether this is a trend that will continue throughout earnings season remains to be seen, but we will continue to update you as reports from Facebook (FB), Amazon (AMZN) and PayPal (PYPL) come in next week.

As the battle for market share in the online payment processing space heats up, PayPal (PYPL) has found an edge over rivals Visa (V), Amazon (AMZN),  Apple (AAPL) and Alphabet (GOOGL). The Holy Grail for retailers and online payment processors is to reduce the number of people who drop off during checkout without completing the purchase. And a new comScore (SCOR) study shows PayPal's 87.5% conversion…

Tech stocks took some hard early hits Friday, but action was much quieter in the S&P 500 and the Dow.The Nasdaq lost 0.7%. The S&P 500 and Dow were mostly unchanged.The stock market today slips into Friday's session with slender gains: the S&P 500 is up 0.5% for the week. The Nasdaq holds less than a 0.2% gain. But nearly two-thirds of the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD advanced for the week through Thursday, with steel makers, ore miners, enterprise software developers and pipeline operators among those posting gains of 5% or more. On the downside, homebuilders, computer makers and meat producers were among the hardest hit.Friday's few scheduled economic reports include a preliminary manufacturing purchasing managers index estimate from researcher Markit at 9:45 a.m. ET. Baker Hughes (BHI) delivers its weekly rig count report at 1 p.m.WTI crude oil futures for June delivery rose nearly 2% to $43.92 a barrel. Gold eased a few bucks to around $1,247 an ounce -- still up more than 1% for the week. Silver and platinum were ahead more than 5% for the week. Natural gas added 1% Friday, nearing a 10% weekly gain. The dollar gained strength, particularly against the yen. Bonds held effectively flat.In stocks, big names were in motion all over the map.Microsoft (MSFT) and Alphabet (GOOGL) shed 7% and 4%, respectively, in early trading.Late Thursday, Microsoft's fiscal Q3 sales and earnings missed consensus expectations, and management's revenue guidance stopped short of analyst estimates. Alphabet earnings and sales also missed targets in its Q1 report. Analyst chatter was active in both stocks Friday.Starbucks (SBUX) and Visa (V) dropped 3% in early action following their quarterly reports late Thursday. Visa said spending in the U.S. remained "reasonably strong," but a strong dollar and weak oil prices were creating headwinds in cross-border spending. Starbucks earnings met, but revenue missed analyst projections.McDonald's (MCD) edged 0.4% higher.  Its Q1 earnings jumped 22% and easily topped expectations. Revenue slipped less than expected and global same store sales rose more than 6%, vs. expectations of less than 5%. The stock ended Thursday less than 1% above a 124.93 buy point from a seven-week cup base.Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) spiked 24% on news revenue slipped less than expected in Q1, and guidance implied a possible turnaround after seven quarters of revenue declines. Losses for the quarter were also slightly lighter than forecast, and the company announced a $293 million deal to license its processor technology to Tianjin Haiguang Advanced Technology Investment, a unit of the Chinese Academy of Sciences.Hanesbrands (HBI) bolted 6% higher after reporting positive Q1 results late Thursday. The clothing maker's shares have been fighting to regain and hold support at their 40-week moving average since July.

You know an ETF is beloved when it has a nickname.Just ask investors in PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), aka Cubes. QQQ corrected 18% after peaking at 115.75 in December, but the recent rally has brought it within 4% of that old high.Among its 106 stock holdings, a dozen have soared more than 20% in the past three months. They include Applied Materials (AMAT), Broadcom (AVGO), Mattel (MAT), Tesla Motors (TSLA) and Yahoo (YHOO).Here are 20 fun facts about Nasdaq-100, the underlying index, for fans of Cubes:QQQ has powered investors' portfolios to bigger gains than SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) in the past decade. A $10,000 investment in QQQ ETF on April 14, 2006, would have grown to $28,615 today. That's an 11.1% average annual return vs. 7.1% for SPY.

Grant Chen's Seattle restaurant netted just $8,856.57 last year after he had to start paying a minimum wage of $11 an hour. Starbucks (SBUX) raked in about $2.8 billion.So here's a puzzle: How can it be that the city's minimum-wage law puts Chen, a decidedly small-time restaurant owner, in the same large-employer category as Starbucks CEO Howard Schulz?You might call it guilt by association. Chen, a second-generation Chinese American, pooled together retirement savings with a few friends, along with loans from family members, and used the money to buy a franchise of a fast-casual chain that could provide the stability of a familiar brand, training and procedures that wouldn't require them to reinvent the wheel.Yet now national chains like McDonald's (MCD) that use the franchise model are under political and legal attack on multiple fronts. Small businesses — many of them minority-owned — are suffering collateral damage.Under the Seattle law, and potentially to a much greater extent under New York state's minimum-wage hike for fast-food outlets, small-business owners are being penalized for their association with large corporations that license out their brands.Discriminating against franchises "paints the cross hairs on a disadvantaged portion of the population that utilizes the franchise model because the barriers to entry are low," Chen wrote in a blog post. The title: "Seattle's $15 Minimum Wage Is Driving My Restaurant Out Of Business."The crackdown on franchising comes even as minority ownership of franchises is surging, providing a tried and true method of democratizing the benefits of capitalism. The latest data from the Census Bureau released late in 2015 show that among businesses with at least 10 employees who operate franchises, 17.5% were minority-owned in 2012, up from 13.8% in 2007. Meanwhile, outside the franchise business, just 10.8% of firms with 10-plus workers were minority-owned.This year, Chen and Starbucks have to pay a minimum of $13 an hour, rising to $15 in 2017, with inflation adjustments thereafter. Smaller employers, those with 500 workers or fewer, get two extra years before they have to pay $15.In New York state, where the minimum-wage just began rising toward $15 an hour for quick-service chains with at least 30 U.S. locations, even small-business operators with a single location are on the hook for the higher wage. Meanwhile, the state's minimum wage for everyone else is $9 an hour, at least for now.The higher New York wage applies to a broad range of limited-service or takeout places, including Starbucks, Yum Brands' (YUM) Taco Bell, Shake Shack (SHAK), Dunkin' Donuts (DNKN), Jamba Juice (JMBA), Wendy's (WEN) and Subway.The earliest consequences of this attack on national franchises are mostly confined to Seattle and New York state. Yet the consequences for the franchise business model could be incredibly far-reaching if courts uphold the National Labor Relations Board decision to designate McDonald's a joint employer of the 90% of its workers who are hired, managed and paid by franchise operators.That case, now being argued before an NLRB administrative law judge in Chicago, could put companies that use the franchise model on the hook for labor violations by the franchisees that operate company-branded restaurants."To protect yourself, you would have to manage the employees," said Andy Puzder, CEO of CKE Restaurants, the company behind chains Carl's Jr. and Hardee's."At that point, the 4% royalty doesn't work anymore," Puzder said, referring to the common 4% of revenue that goes to the franchisor as payment for everything it provides to help a franchise succeed.Further, if the franchisor is found to be a joint employer with its franchisees, that would effectively turn small businesses into large ones and create new liability to provide workers clocking 30 hours a week with health insurance under ObamaCare's employer mandate, says David Kaufmann, whose law firm Kaufmann Gildin & Robbins represents franchise industry employers.But the primary objective in rewriting decades of law and regulations governing the franchise industry is "unionizing workers at franchises," Kaufmann said.Unquestionably, the push to unionize would be easier. Instead of organizing workers at individual franchises or groups of outlets under common ownership, unions could deal directly with the corporations behind the brands.The big flaw in the NLRB's case is that McDonald's, like other big franchisors, doesn't control the workers at its franchise locations and doesn't have the power to tell franchise operators how much to pay in wages. That reality was evident when McDonald's said last year it would raise its starting wage at company-owned locations to $1 above the local minimum wage. Franchise operators were reportedly less than thrilled by the move, likely because their workers wanted the same deal. But they had the ultimate decision.The NLRB joint-employer designation would fundamentally redefine the role of a franchisee, from someone who puts up risk capital and runs a business to make a profit into one among perhaps hundreds or even thousands of middle managers in a corporate empire."The ability to run my own business was the very reason I put my savings on the line to become a franchisee," wrote Amir Siddiqi in a Wall Street Journal op-ed last year.Born in Pakistan, Siddiqi came to the U.S. at age 19 in 1985 and worked as a dishwasher at a Carl's Jr. across the street from his community college. He eventually worked his way up through management of the parent company, then seized the chance to become his own boss, putting up all of his savings and borrowing the rest needed to buy three Carl's Jr. franchises. Now he has more than 40 restaurants and 900 workers, including teenagers and immigrants working their first jobs.Making franchisors joint employers, Siddiqi said, could "destroy a road to the American dream for people who are willing to take some risks for the chance to build a business and a better life."The NLRB's joint-employer rule is expected to wind up before the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals and possibly the Supreme Court before it takes effect. Meanwhile, the International Association of Franchises has joined business owners in asking the Supreme Court to invalidate Seattle's discriminatory treatment of franchises. Among the petitioners is Ronald Oh, whose dad fled North Korea as a youngster. Now the family has its livelihood invested in a Holiday Inn Express (IHG) with a few dozen employees."The way to become rich is to put all your eggs in one basket and then watch that basket," Oh said at a hearing on the wage hike, quoting Andrew Carnegie. "This is our basket, and the eggs are the lives of my entire extended family. We are watching that basket carefully."

The stock market rallied nicely at the open Wednesday as overseas factors, earnings reports and economic data all influenced early trade.The Nasdaq led the way, rising 0.9%. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 picked up 0.7% each.The stock market today benefited from a positive mood started in Asia. China's March exports surged 12% from a a year ago, the first rise in eight months, according to the General Administration of Customs. Imports declined less than 8%, vs. a 14% drop in February. The export improvement was partially due to a sharp drop in exports in March 2015. Strong exports were also helped by a weaker yuan.Hong Kong's Hang Seng index responded with a 3.2% gain. The Shanghai Composite climbed 1.4%. In Japan, the yen continued lower against the dollar, helping send the Nikkei 225 ahead 2.8%.The positive tone carried over into Europe, where markets pushed strong gains in afternoon trade. The CAC 40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX traded up more than 2% each. London's FTSE 100 showed a 1.4% gain.The overseas momentum helped compensate for the drag caused by oil and gold, both of which traded briskly lower. West Texas Intermediate traded down 1%, but held firmly above $41 a barrel. Gold futures were off nearly 1% to $1,250 an ounce.In U.S. economic news, inflation received a tame report card, as producer prices eased 0.1% in March, the Labor Department estimated, well below the 0.3% increase expected by consensus forecasts. Declines in cost of services apparently offset rebounding energy prices. Core prices, minus energy and food, also dipped 0.1%, vs. forecasts for a 0.2% increase.Retail sales also dropped in March, down 0.3%, Commerce Department data showed. Consensus expectations called for a 0.1% increase. Minus automobiles, sales rose 0.2% -- below the consensus estimate for a 0.4% gain.The Census Bureau offers up February business inventories data at 10 a.m. ET, followed by the Energy Information Administration's weekly oil inventories report at 10:30. The Federal Reserve's beige book report is due out at 2 p.m.JPMorgan (JPM) and Goldman Sachs (GS) paced the Dow in the early going, rising 3% each.JPMorgan outperformed after its Q1 report showed earnings and revenue falling less than anticipated. JPMorgan's Q1 results showed consumer and community banking growing net income 12% on a 4% rise in revenue. Investment banking revenue dropped 24%.Other banks tapped into the momentum. Bank of America (BAC), Wells Fargo (WFC) and PNC Financial Services (PNC) -- all scheduled to report results on Thursday -- rose 2% apiece. Overseas banks were also in serious motion: Germany's Deutsche Bank (DB) leapt 6%, London-based HSBC Holdings (HSBC) swung up 5%. Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS), Lloyd's Banking Group (LYG) and UBS Group (UBS) all climbed 3%.Among other companies reporting quarterly results, Adtran (ADTN) jumped 4% after a positive report late Tuesday. Railroad CSX (CSX) rose 1%, as revenue missed and earnings just met analyst consensus estimates, but management reported firmer pricing and rising volumes in automotive and other segments.Beyond earnings, biotech drug maker Medivation (MDVN) sparked up 8% after Bloomberg reported the company had snubbed a buyout offer from French drug giant Sanofi (SNY). Shares of Sanofi added 0.6%.China's Baidu (BIDU) and JD.Com (JD) led the Nasdaq 100, up 3% and 4% respecitively. S&P 500 name Harley Davidson (HOG) rebounded 3.5%. The stock tanked 14% last week on a string of critical analyst notes.Early IBD 50 leaders included Facebook (FB). Shares added more than 1%. The social networking heavy found quiet support at its 50-day line on Tuesday, ending 6% below a 117.09 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.Coffee chain Starbucks (SBUX) added 2% after Tuesday's gap down in heavy trade. The stock managed to find support at the converged 50- and 200-day moving averages. That is a positive, but shares have been unable to rise clear of those lines of support as they've climbed the right side of a shallow six-month consolidation.
