Brinker International (EAT) and Red Robin Gourmet Burgers (RRGB) are already among the better restaurant stocks, with IBD Composite Ratings of 93 and 96, respectively.Can the two companies gain an even bigger edge thanks to a technology designed to improve the dining experience?Maybe so, according to a new research note from Sterne Agee analyst Lynne Collier.That technology, made by Dallas-based tech firm Ziosk, is a Wi-Fi enabled tablet that lets diners order at the table, entertain themselves before or while dining, and quickly pay their bills when they're finished dining.In a note released Wednesday, Collier said Ziosk's technology "will transform the industry and enable casual dining to much more effectively compete with fast casual."She also said early adopters of the technology "will be at a competitive advantage." Those early adopters include Brinker, owner of the Chili's and Maggiano's chains; and Red Robin, owner of its namesake chain of burger restaurants."We expect rollout to additional casual dining companies over the next 12 to 24 months," Collier noted, though she didn't say which companies might be part of the rollout.Longer term, she reckons that other segments of the restaurant industry, including fine-dining establishments, will be users as well."The model works as a revenue sharing arrangement as sponsorship and gaming revenues pay for the cost of the hardware," Collier said.She cites a few advantages of adopting Ziosk technology, including quicker service and higher checks due to an expected increase in the number of drinks and desserts ordered. She also says more kids might convince their parents to patronize Ziosk-enabled restaurants because of the tablet's gaming capabilities.Red Robin set a record stock high of 89.46 on March 24 and currently trades near 84. Brinker set a high of 63.40 on Feb. 19 and currently trades near 60.Both belong to IBD's Retail-Restaurants group, which ranks No. 6 out of 197 industries tracked. Among the five biggest stocks by market cap, Starbucks (SBUX) and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) are the highest rated. with Composite Ratings of 96 and 92, respectively.

Stocks settled back slightly going into the close Friday, but managed to hold most of the day's gains despite weakness in chip stocks. Dunkin' Brands Group (DNKN) delivered its lowest EPS growth in years last quarter and is expected to post only single-digit gains over the next three quarters — but investors still have reason to like the seller of doughnuts and coffee.

Dunkin' boasts a strong IBD Composite Rating of 93, has seen its share price rise about 15% since hitting a five-month low Dec. 19, and belongs to a Retail-Restaurant group that ranks No. 9 out of 197 industries that IBD tracks.

Those positive signs come even amid slower earnings growth at the Canton, Mass.-based company, which ended a years-long run of double-digit EPS gains by posting a 7% year-over-year increase during its 2014 fourth quarter.
Here are three reasons to feel perky about Dunkin':
 Improving comps: In a new research note, analyst Stephen Anderson of Miller Tabak says that he expects Dunkin's same-restaurant sales to accelerate toward the high end of guidance in 2015.

He cites a slight rise in menu prices, the introduction of new products such as cold blended drinks, and increased enrollment in Dunkin's DDPerks rewards program — changes that Anderson estimates will add 50 to 75 basis points to 2015 same-restaurant sales.
"We also argue that continued job gains and, to a lesser extent, lower gasoline costs will fuel breakfast traffic for the industry," Anderson noted.

He reckons that Dunkin' can take market share away from rivals such as McDonald's (MCD), in part because the latter company has less wiggle room to offer heavy promotions on coffee and other breakfast and lunch items.
 Lower coffee costs: Even with recent volatility in coffee prices, Dunkin' executives expect year-over-year coffee costs to be flat to down slightly in 2015.
"Previously they had expected a slight headwind from coffee costs," Anderson noted.
Dunkin' doesn't get a direct bottom-line boost from lower coffee costs because almost all of its units are franchised, so the franchisees get the benefit.
However, Anderson said, "We think there will be an indirect benefit as more profitable franchisees accelerate unit expansion."
More units means more franchise revenue for Dunkin'.
 Dunkin' K-Cups: Dunkin' K-Cups' being rolled out in grocery and online channels should be an "incremental catalyst" for the company, Anderson said, though probably more for 2016 than 2015.

Dunkin' management will wait until the release of its first-quarter results to provide more specific details on expanded distribution of Dunkin' K-Cups, he said. For now, they are distributed exclusively at its Dunkin' Donuts restaurants nationally and at its Baskin-Robbins locations on the West Coast.

Dunkin' K-Cups currently contribute about $150 million in total sales for Dunkin', Anderson said: "Although there is the risk of cannibalization at Dunkin' restaurants, we think there is the potential for DNKN to double K-Cup sales to $300 million through the grocery/retail and online channels."

Meanwhile, coffee powerhouse Starbucks (SBUX) also made news during its annual shareholders meeting Wednesday when it announced a 2-for-1 stock split as well as plans to roll out a new delivery service later this year.
The split goes into effect April 8 and will begin trading on a split-adjusted basis the next day. It will be the company's sixth stock split since going public.
Starbucks' delivery initiative includes mobile order and pay, evening menus and more drive-through locations. The pilot delivery program will initially be launched in New York and Seattle.

As Starbucks (SBUX) continues to expand its grip beyond coffee and espresso drinks, the coffee-shop giant's Evolution Fresh brand is partnering with yogurt maker Dannon to bring smoothies and parfaits to its menus, plus a ready-to-eat item to grocery store shelves.

The smoothies, made with Starbucks' Evolution Fresh cold-pressed juice and Dannon yogurt, will be available at 4,300 Starbucks locations in the Pacific Northwest, Northern California, and certain in-supermarket Starbucks. Flavors include strawberry, mango carrot and a vegetable-and-fruit option. The expansion follows a pilot test last year of the Evolution Fresh smoothie.

Shares were down 0.4% on the stock market today. After breaking out of a flat base on Jan. 23 with an 84.30 buy point, the stock did not remain in a buy range for long, and on March 19 hit a new high of 99.20.

In May, Dannon and the Starbucks-owned juicery will bring fruit-and-Greek-yogurt parfaits to Starbucks nationwide. The partnership also includes bringing ready-to-eat fruit-on-the-bottom Greek yogurts to grocery stores in the summer.
Starbucks intends to double its food sales in five years with evening menus and a small-batch artisan coffee concept, among other items.
Its aggressive plans for a wider reach also involve mobile order-and-pay, drive-thrus and a pilot delivery program in New York and Seattle.
The company is a member of IBD's Retail-Restaurants group, joined by the likes of Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) and popular recent IPOs Shake Shack (SHAK) and El Pollo Loco (LOCO).

Toys R Us, the world's largest toy chain, plans to leave its flagship store in New York's Times Square as it faces an expected rent hike.

The 110,000-square-foot store at 1514 Broadway, with an indoor Ferris wheel and mechanical Tyrannosaurus Rex dinosaur, is too big for any single tenant, said C. Bradley Mendelson, vice chairman at Cushman & Wakefield, who is handling leasing for building-owner Bow Tie Partners. The landlord plans to break up the space, Mendelson said."The configuration of space is just too expensive for any one tenant," Mendelson said. "Market rates have changed substantially. It has nothing to do with Toys' ability. Toys has been a very good tenant for the last 15, 16 years."The move reflects rapid rent growth in the Times Square "bow tie" — the blocks immediately surrounding the area where Broadway and Seventh Avenue cross, often called the crossroads of the world. Retailers clamoring for access to the square's tourist traffic have been driving rents higher.Rates for ground-floor retail space in the bow tie area averaged $2,317 a square foot in late 2014, higher than anywhere in Manhattan except Fifth Avenue between 49th and 59th streets, according to a report by the Real Estate Board of New York. Three years earlier, the average was $1,433 a square foot.'Proud Resident'Toys R Us has been "a proud resident of Times Square since our international flagship store opened there," Linda Connors, a spokeswoman for the company, said in an emailed statement. "The lease for our store in Times Square expires in 2016 and, as previously noted, we have been reviewing our lease renewal options. We have not signed a lease agreement for a new location, and any rumors regarding this ongoing process are just that."The ground floor of 21,000 square feet is being marketed for $2,500 a square foot, its second-floor space for $350 a square foot, and the lower level at $150 a square foot, he said. There are four other retail tenants in the 150,000-square-foot building: Foot Locker (FL) and Swatch stores, a Starbucks (SBUX) coffee shop and the Bond 45 restaurant. Their leases all expire in February, the same time as Toys R Us, he said.Toys R Us may relocate to the retail storefronts across the square at the Marriott Marquis Hotel, where Vornado Realty Trust (VNO) controls the retail portion of the property, according to the Commercial Observer, which reported the retailer's move. Vornado, which owns a stake in the toy retailer, has installed Times Square's largest digital advertising sign above its stores.About 43,000 square feet of retail space are immediately available at the hotel, according to Vornado's website. Wendi Kopsick, a Vornado spokeswoman, said the company would have no comment.The model dinosaur and Ferris wheel are Toys R Us property, and could be used at its new store, "wherever that may be," Mendelson said. There have been discussions with Toys R Us about taking less space but "nothing ongoing right now" with the retailer, he said. The Times Square store was a staging area for marketing for the company, which has struggled in competition with the likes of Wal-Mart (WMT) and Amazon.com (AMZN).

U.S. stocks showed hesitation Wednesday after the previous session's strong price gains. The Nasdaq slipped 0.4%, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.3% and 0.2%, respectively. Volume in the stock market today dropped vs. Tuesday's already below-average pace.

Blue chips were mostly down. Only a handful of stocks in the Dow rose and those in tiny steps. On the downside, Chevron (CVX) carved off 1% in slow turnover as West Texas intermediate crude oil fell 3.5%. Chevron, an integrated oil company, has rebounded about 30% off its late August low but remains about 33% off its July 2014 high.

An integrated oil company is involved in many facets of the business: exploration, production, refining and distribution. From late June 2014, when crude oil began its fast price slide, the price of oil is now down 64%; U.S. explorers, down 63%; integrated, down 41%; and refiners, down 21%.

In the IBD 50 — a list of the best stocks in fundamentals and technicals — mortgage software provider Ellie Mae (ELLI) took the hardest hit, dropping more than 2%. But volume was about 20% below average.
Housing-related stocks got some bad news as November pending home sales dropped unexpectedly.

However, homebuilder D.R. Horton (DHI), a Leaderboard stock, shrugged the news off. The Nasdaq turned a 0.4% loss into a 0.3% gain. Biotechs and software issues outperformed. The S&P 500 pared a 0.5% deficit to 0.1%, while the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2%. Volume was tracking sharply lower across the board in the stock market today compared to the same time Friday.

Among highly rated stocks,Globant (GLOB) rallied nearly 4% to an all-time high and cleared a 35.10 buy point in heavy trading. About two hours into the session, the thin stock already matched its 50-day average volume.

Nike (NKE) climbed more than 1% to another new high after being upgraded to buy from hold at BB&T. It's now 12% past a 117.82 buy point. The athletic apparel and footwear giant was recently mentioned in the New Highs column.

On the downside, Microsemi (MSCC) dropped 6% on news that it offered $2.2 billion to buy PMC-Sierra (PMCS). Its bid topped a $2 billion buyout offer by Apple (AAPL) supplier Skyworks Solutions (SWKS). Microsemi fell below a 37.51 buy point from a consolidation cleared Friday. PMC shares jumped 14%.

Valeant (VRX) slumped 6% despite beating views and raising guidance. Before the open, the Canadian drugmaker posted adjusted Q3 earnings of $2.74 a share, up from $2.11 a year ago. Sales grew 36%, the third straight period of acceleration, to almost $2.79 billion. It lifted its full-year sales forecast to $11 billion-$11.2 billion from $10.7 billion-$11.1 billion.

Profit is now expected at $11.67 to $11.87 a share, up from a prior outlook of $11.50 to $11.80. Last week, Valeant said it received subpoenas from federal prosecutors in Massachusetts and New York, requesting information about its patient-assistance programs and drug-pricing decisions.

Starbucks (SBUX) says it wants its baristas to spark conversations about race. Here's a topic: Its coffee shops help spark local gentrification and home prices, Zillow data show."Racial inequality is a topic rarely discussed in a corporate setting and seldom encouraged as a coffee shop conversation. That is changing as Starbucks and USA TODAY embark on an initiative called Race Together," Starbucks said in a statement Monday.Baristas can now choose to give customers cups with "Race Together" or #RaceTogether written on them. The #RaceTogether hashtag trended on Twitter (TWTR), but frequently in mockery. People accused Starbucks of hubris and self-satisfaction and criticized the idea of pressuring service staff to confront customers ordering a Frappuccino.CEO Howard Schultz conceded that the effort won't solve racism, but said in a statement it's an "opportunity to begin to re-examine how we can create a more empathetic and inclusive society."However, Starbucks' actual corporate strategy appears to be finding more exclusive areas for new locations. Starbucks stores tend to open in wealthier areas, and those areas see faster home appreciation than other neighborhoods.That's according to Zillow (Z) CEO Spencer Rascoff and chief economist Stan Humphries, authors of "Zillow Talk: The New Rules of Real Estate.""Starbucks equates with venti-sized home-value appreciation," the Zillow execs wrote in a book excerpt published in Quartz. "Moreover, Starbucks seems to be fueling — not following — these higher home values."The typical U.S. home was valued at $102,000 in 1997, rising 65% to $168,000 by 2014. But homes within a quarter mile of a Starbucks appreciated 96% over that span, from $137,000 to $269,000.The authors also studied whether this was a Starbucks effect, or just a generic coffee shop effect. So they looked at homes near Dunkin' Donuts (DNKN). Dunkin-adjacent homes appreciated faster than the national average — 80% — but less than Starbucks-area dwellings."Whatever the reasons — because they genuinely like drinking coffee, or because they see Starbucks as a proxy for gentrification — it seems pretty clear that people are paying a premium for homes near Starbucks," the authors conclude.Moreover, the Starbucks effect isn't just luck, but reflects "careful, data-driven decisions" on where to site new coffee shops.Gentrification has many benefits, but it can make neighborhoods unaffordable for poor and moderate-income people and families, many of them minorities.Starbucks said it will talk more about its Race Together initiative at Wednesday's annual shareholder meeting.Given that the coffee shop giant sees a barista-Twitter #hashtag campaign as meaningful action, don't expect Starbucks to consider its own impact.USA Today is owned by publishing giant Gannett (GCI).Follow Ed Carson on Twitter: @IBD_ECarson.

The 94-year-old, Columbus, Ohio-based hamburger chain with 400 restaurants is working with global payment security company Elavon to implement layers of security at points-of-sale that include encryption and tokenization, while supporting chip cards and contactless payments, says Susan Carroll,…
Some stocks leave the Big Cap 20 for a good reason, as in "too good."

When a stock takes off and then climbs a long way, eventually the long advance makes it less attractive. This is what happened to Southwest Airlines (LUV), which was working on a fifth-stage base when it dropped out of the Big Cap 20 about a month ago.
A late-stage base is less likely to work than a first- or second-stage base mainly because there are too many funds with nice gains in the stock and ready to take profits.

The flip side of that involves stocks that have more of a rolling, sideways look. This kind of action can reset base counts. While that may sound like a technicality, the action reflects weak holders being pressured out of a stock.
You want the stock to be left with strong holders, so that a breakout doesn't immediately roll over.
There's no guarantee, of course, that such stocks will work or even present a valid buying opportunity, but investors should monitor the situation closely.

After hitting a high in November 2013, Starbucks (SBUX) had been wearing out the lukewarm holders with repeated consolidations that corrected in the 12% to 17% range. The rebounds off the lows were moderate, never exceeding the 2013 high until recently.

The stock gapped up out of a first-stage pattern Jan. 23 in fast trade. So far, the advance hasn't gone further than 12% from the 84.30 buy point. This means the next pattern could be first stage, too.
Even if the stock rises the required 20% to make the next pattern second stage, that's still bullish territory.
Starbucks grew earnings 18% to 22% over the past four fiscal years. (The fiscal year ends in September.) The Street expects EPS to grow 18% this fiscal year and again 18% in fiscal 2016.
Recent earnings revisions have been upward.

Pretax margin was 18.9% last year, the highest in at least nine years. Lower commodity prices helped, but so did price increases. Starbucks rolled out higher prices in the summer of 2014. Prices also were increased in June 2013.
Starbucks' customers are nonchalant about price increases. Market research has shown that most Starbucks customers, stopped after leaving the store, don't know what they paid for the coffee.
How strong is the Starbucks brand? Research by online real estate lister Zillow.com found that when a Starbucks moves into a neighborhood, home prices rise at double the standard rate.
Whole Foods Market (WFM) underwent a long, deep consolidation, also beginning in November 2013. The correction was 45% deep, which isn't ideal.

Starbucks' new holiday-season offerings paid off during the fiscal first quarter, with the coffee giant reporting strong sales and traffic increases on Thursday.

Global same-store sales grew 5%, above some estimates for a 4.8% gain, as traffic increased 2%. Comparable-store sales also rose 5% in the Americas region, which is dominated by the U.S., with traffic growth improving to 2% from 1% in Q4. Comp sales soared 8% in the China/Asia-Pacific region and rose 4% in Europe/Middle East/Africa.
Starbucks (SBUX) shares rallied 4% in late trading after closing up 1.8% in the regular session.
Earnings per share rose 16% to 80 cents, matching analyst estimates. Revenue increased 13% to $4.8 billion, just edging past views. Operating margin widened 80 basis points to 19.5%.

The Q1 revenue gains reflected the acquisition of Starbucks Japan, and also new holiday gift cards, new drinks like the chestnut praline latte, and its "Starbucks for Life" contest, in which winners can get one free item at participating stores for 30 years.
The company said dollars loaded on Starbucks cards spiked to a record $1.6 billion.

"Our re-imagined in-store holiday experience that included a vastly expanded assortment of Starbucks cards, new holiday food, beverage and merchandise offerings and the opportunity to win 'Starbucks for Life' resonated powerfully with our customers and drove both increased traffic and tremendous excitement in our stores and around the Starbucks brand," CEO Howard Schultz said.
The company sees Q2 EPS of 64-65 cents, below analyst views for 68 cents. It narrowed its full-year EPS outlook to $3.09-$3.13 from $3.08-$3.13, still largely below the consensus for $3.13.
Starbucks also named director Kevin Johnson to become COO on March 1, replacing longtime executive Troy Alstead.

The stock market closed mixed Friday after indexes bounced back from an early slump. The Nasdaq rose 0.2% thanks to strength in biotechs, security software and solar stocks.The S&P; 500 fell 0.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average lagged with a 0.3% drop and closed near session lows.Small caps paced the market: The small-cap Russell 2000 climbed 0.6%. Volume rose on the NYSE and edged lower on the Nasdaq, according to early figures.After a serious decline the prior day, Friday's price reversals were encouraging. Yet the market remained locked in a long sideways trend.Stocks sank at the open as a better-than-expected jobs report for May triggered a slide in bond prices.Energy stocks rose after OPEC left its output targets unchanged, as expected. Solar shares jumped after China-based JA Solar 's (JASO) chief executive offered to buy the company and take it private.Financials also helped lead the stock market today. Bank of America (BAC) rose more than 2% and closed back near a 24.88 buy point. JPMorgan (JPM) rose 2% and hit a new high. Thinly traded BofI Holdings (BOFI) rose 2% and topped the 97.78 buy point of a long cup-with-handle base.It was a strong day for the IBD 50, with the average component up about 1.3%. Volume was just average or light for most of the 50 stocks, though.

Shares climbed 3.4% in the stock market today. Rival Starbucks (SBUX) was up 0.8%. Titanium dioxide, a whitening agent used in toothpaste and sunscreen, is known to contain nanomaterials. As…
Coffee and doughnut restaurant chain Dunkin' Donuts (DNKN) looks to expand its footprint in the Midwest.

Dunkin' Brands, which operates more than 11,000 Dunkin' Donuts shops and Baskin-Robbins ice cream stores, said Wednesday it's signed development agreements with two existing franchise owners to add a total 46 restaurants in Indiana over the next few years.

Franchisee Kings Point Ventures, which currently operates more than 70 Dunkin' Donuts restaurants in several states, plans to develop 38 new stores in Indianapolis and Fort Wayne, the first one slated to open later this year. Franchisee Bud Patel, who operates more than 20 Dunkin' outlets, plans to develop eight locations in Lafayette and Indianapolis.

Financial terms weren't disclosed, but Dunkin' said it was extending development incentives to its franchisees, including reduced royalty fees for three years and up to $10,000 in local store marketing support for timely openings.
Dunkin' shares were up less than 1% in Wednesday afternoon trading on the stock market today.

Dunkin has consolidated since March 2014 in a range with a 53.05 pivot point, and Wednesday was trading roughly in the middle of the range, above both its 50-day and 200-day lines. After six quarters of double-digit profit growth, Dunkin's earnings per share growth eased to 7% last quarter. Consensus is for a 9% increase this quarter.
Rival and No. 1 global coffeehouse chain Starbucks (SBUX) also upped its game this week.
Starbucks on Tuesday announced the launch of a premium, small-lot coffee delivery subscription service.

For a $24 monthly fee, Starbucks Reserve Roastery subscriptions will send small-lot coffees that are otherwise only available by visiting the company's roastery in Seattle. The company ensures delivery within three to five days of roasting, depending on location.

Starbucks also announced several promotions including availability of "super-premium" small-lot coffees roasted at the Seattle Reserve, such as Brazil Nova Resende and Sulawesi Pango Pango flavors, for a limited time in Starbucks restaurants. Starbucks in recent years has added various food and non-coffee beverages, including custom-made soda drinks, to expand its menu offerings.
Starbucks boasts a near-best 98 IBD Composite Rating, meaning it's outperformed 98% of all stocks on key metrics such as sales and profit growth. Shares were up about 1%.

Companies that provide food and drink have turned out to be a profitable trend for investors who ply the big-cap part of the stock market.
Whole Foods Market (WFM), Starbucks (SBUX) and Constellation Brands (STZ) all made the Big-Cap 20 list Monday.

Whole Foods is recovering from a disappointing earnings report last May. The company reported EPS that was flat from a year ago. The stock gapped down and closed nearly 19% lower. It traded sideways into November, then starting rising, building the right side of a long, deep base.

It got back on track with an earnings report Nov. 6 when it gapped up 12% on a more favorably received earnings report. It gapped up again on an earnings report Feb. 12, but it needs more work before it's buyable.
In the most recent report, earnings and sales rose 10%. In the next report, analysts expect EPS to grow 11%.
The five-year annualized EPS growth rate is 24%. Analysts expect earnings growth of 12% this year and 11% next year.
The return on equity for 2014 was 15%, a bit below the 17% benchmark investors should seek.
Starbucks has been a growth story even longer than Whole Foods. Both stocks suffered serious declines during the 2008 financial crisis and have come back and stormed to new all-time highs.

Starbucks reported earnings after the close Jan. 22 and gapped out of a flat base the next morning, finishing the day nearly 7% higher. The flat base could also be considered the slightly high handle of a long consolidation going back to November 2013.
It's now well extended from any buy point.
The most recent earnings report showed a 16% EPS year-over-year growth rate. Revenue was up 13%. Analysts are forecasting another 16% increase in the next report.

The five-year annualized EPS growth rate is 21%. Analysts forecast 18% growth this year and next. The ROE is an impressive 42%, boosted somewhat by debt. Starbucks has produced steady earnings growth the past five year, showing an Earnings Stability Factor of 4 on a 0 to 99 scale, where low numbers correspond to steady earnings growth.

Constellation Brands (STZ) produces and distributes alcoholic beverages. Its brands include Black Velvet, Paul Masson, Clos du Bois, Wild Horse, Almaden and Inglenook. It successfully tested its 50-day moving average in December and is well extended from any buy point.
Earnings have been slowing the past two quarters. In the most recent report, EPS grew 12% with a 7% increase in revenue. In the next report, analysts forecast a 16% increase in earnings.

The five-year EPS growth rate is 19%. Analysts expect 34% this year and 12% next.Companies that provide food and drink have turned out to be a profitable trend for investors who ply the big-cap part of the stock market.Whole Foods Market (WFM), Starbucks (SBUX) and Constellation Brands (STZ) all made the Big-Cap 20 list Monday.Whole Foods is recovering from a disappointing earnings report last May. Two highly ranked restaurant stocks made the Stock Spotlight screen this week after reporting earnings. The quarterly reports were good news for one and no so good for the other.

BJ's Restaurants (BJRI) reported earnings that were 417% above the year-ago figure. In the prior quarter, EPS rose 77% after seven straight quarters of earnings decline. Following the report late Wednesday, the stock gapped up out of a base and closed up 14% on volume more than 500% above average.
BJ'S operates 157 restaurants under the BJ's Restaurant & Brewhouse or small-format BJ's Pizza & Grill. It specializes in craft beer.
Because of a couple of years of declining earnings, it has a five-year annualized EPS growth rate of just 6%. Analysts forecast a 25% increase this year and a 26% increase in 2016.

But the reaction to earnings was no party for Fiesta Restaurant Group (FRGI). After Thursday's close, it reported EPS that was 70% above a year ago. The stock traded higher after the close, but dropped quickly once the regular session began Friday. Wedbush reiterated an outperform rating, but Raymond James downgraded it from strong buy to outperform.
Fiesta operates or franchises 329 Taco Cabana and Pollo Tropical restaurants.
The stock broke timidly out of a flat base earlier this month, then backed away from a 64.28 buy point. It's back near that level, although it has heavy volume on the downside.

The 58-stock restaurant industry is ranked No. 3 out of 197 groups, but earnings reports have been a mixed bag. Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) reported Feb. 3. But the fast-casual chain gapped down and fell nearly 7% the next day. It hasn't been able to recover its 50-day moving average since then.

In contrast, the global coffeehouse chain Starbucks (SBUX) gapped up out of a base past 84.30 on its fiscal Q1 report and has been rising since then. The Nasdaq was on track midday Wednesday to break its five-session win streak, though close enough to the break-even line to leave the outcome in doubt.

Volume was running about 10% lower vs. the previous day's pace. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average appeared set to end three-session win streaks. The S&P 500 and Dow were down 0.2% each, while the Nasdaq was just under the break-even line.

Visa (V) served as a drag on the Dow, falling 0.5% in soft volume. The Dow is a price-weighted index, and Visa is the highest-priced stock in the Dow. However, that will soon change. Visa is planning a 4-for-1 split March 19, which will ax its weighting in the Dow.
While the major indexes were struggling, the Dow Jones transportation and utility averages stayed positive, adding 0.2% and 0.6%, respectively.
Tank barge operator Kirby Corporation (KEX) led the transportation stocks with a 2% gain. Kirby has been in a nasty correction since late September and is about 35% off its high.
Among top-rated stocks, Apple (AAPL) headed toward its 11th gain in the past 12 sessions, though it was barely up in midday trade.
Chip designer Cavium (CAVM) thrust more than 5% to a new high in heavy turnover.
Starbucks (SBUX) also hit a new high, gaining almost 1%. Volume, though, was below average.

West Texas intermediate crude oil dropped 1%, slipping just under $53 a barrel. Stocks raced to an impressive gain Thursday, propelled by the European Central Bank's announcement of asset purchases, as well as earnings reports from airlines buoyed by falling oil prices.
The Nasdaq rose 1.8%. The S&P; 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average each gained 1.5%. Volume was higher on both exchanges in the stock market today.

United Continental (UAL) gained altitude, rising nearly 5% to a 15-year high despite reporting earnings that missed analyst expectations. The company said it expects pretax margins of 5%-7% this year, above the low single digits of recent years.
Alaska Air (ALK) beat estimates and also closed up nearly 5%, a new all-time high.
The airline industry group rose 4.3%, the best of 197 groups tracked by IBD. Banks were also strong. Oil stocks were among the worst performers as crude oil prices fell 2.6% to the 46 level.
After the close, Starbucks (SBUX) was up sharply after reporting fiscal Q1 earnings that met estimates and just beat on revenue, although Q2 guidance fell short.
Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) was volatile after the close. It reported EPS of $1.26 vs. estimates for $1.19.
At 10 a.m. ET Friday, the National Association of Realtors reports existing-home sales for December. Economists forecast 5.05 million units vs. 4.93 million for the prior month.

The Big Cap 20 is showing itself to be a good representation of today's market leadership, as technology, health care and consumer stocks dominate the list.A glance of the IBD Smart NYSE + Nasdaq Tables shows chips, medical, apparel, retail and other technology sectors make up most of the top 10 sectors. That's a fitting reflection of what you find in the Big Cap 20. Most of the 20 stocks can be categorized in one of those areas.In technology, a couple of chipmakers rank among the leading big caps, along with some business-service tech companies.Analog Devices (ADI) is one of the more interesting charts. The stock broke out of a cup-shaped base on Feb. 17 and has risen 3% from that entry.The chipmaker earned 63 cents a share excluding items for the January-ended quarter, beating expectations. Sales rose 23%, as the top line continued an accelerating trend of growth.Analysts noted strength in its industrial and automotive markets.Apple (AAPL), a tech leader that could be viewed as a consumer stock too, is another high-tech stock that's found a home in the Big Cap 20. The stock is near new highs, extended from its breakout past 119.85 last month.In the medical sector, drugmakers Biogen Idec (BIIB), Pharmacyclics (PCYC) and Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) have rallied in recent weeks and account for some of the best percentage gains in the Big Cap 20 over the past couple of weeks.UnitedHealth Group (UNH) and Cigna (CI) are part of a broad rally in HMO stocks.While those medical leaders are extended, Mylan (MYL) is setting up in a base with a 59.70 buy point.However, its shares fell moderately after the close Monday, when the company reported Q4 earnings of $1.05 a share, an increase of 35%. Sales rose 18% to $2.08 billion.Mylan forecast 2015 revenues of $9.6 billion to $10.1 billion.In consumer stocks, the big cap leaders run the gamut of auto-parts chain O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY), Starbucks (SBUX) and discount retailer Ross Stores (ROST).Ross Stores shined Friday as its earnings report sent shares gapping up to a 7% gain and a record high.For the first two months of 2015, the Big Cap 20 has acquitted itself quite satisfactorily. It rose 6.9%, far better than the 2.2% gain for the S&P 500, which is a broad gauge of big-capitalization stocks.Qorvo (QRVO) may be an unfamiliar name on a list filled with familiar brands. The company is the name adopted when RF Micro Devices and TriQuint merged to create a leading manufacturer of cellular radio frequency technology used for wireless communications, military and other applications.The stock is consolidating, while finding support at the 10-week moving average.

Restaurant stocks have been on a strong run of late, with leaders like Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) and Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) trading near record highs and helping to push the Retail-Restaurants group to No. 8 out of 197 industries that IBD tracks.
The sector might be poised for even more good times in the months ahead if recent National Restaurant Association data are any indication.

The association's Restaurant Performance Index (RPI) for November, released just before the New Year's break, shows that restaurant operators are bullish about their prospects over the next couple of quarters, thanks to a strong operating environment and favorable macro trends.
The overall RPI reading in November was 102.1, down slightly from October's 102.8 but still above 100, meaning that the restaurant industry is in expansion rather than contraction mode.

Importantly, the RPI's Expectations Index component — which measures restaurant operators' six-month outlook for same-store sales, employees, capital expenditures and business conditions — stood at 102.8 in November. That's up from 102.5 in October and marks the 25th straight reading above 100 — a sign that restaurant operators are optimistic that business conditions will continue to improve in coming months.
Restaurant operators have benefited from a couple of recent trends, said analyst Stephen Anderson of institutional trading firm Miller Tabak in a note published Friday morning.
"Lower fuel prices and a constructive jobs picture contributed to a new cyclical high in operator expectations in November," Anderson wrote.

He added, "The jobs picture — which we see as the most important driver for the sector — is on more solid footing as 2015 begins," In addition, "a mild start to the winter of 2014-2015 also should help December same-restaurant sales."
These trends have helped the Retail-Restaurants group make it back into IBD's Top 10 industry groups after falling outside the Top 100 six months ago.

In addition to Chipotle and Buffalo Wild Wings, leading stocks in the group by IBD Composite Rating (which factors in earnings growth, stock gains and other metrics) include Nathan's Famous (NATH) and Texas Roadhouse (TXRH). Technology stocks are thriving as the Nasdaq composite closes in on 5,000 after a big February advance. Savvy investors know to focus on the very best companies.IBD's Screen Center runs a Tech Leaders screen. Today's Tech Leaders is on Internets. This article does a second sort focusing based on expected earnings growth in the next quarter. Here are the five best.GrubHub Eating Rivals' LunchGrubHub (GRUB), which came public at 26 in April IPO, provides online and mobile food ordering services for 30,000 restaurants in the U.S. and London, with an average commission of 14.5%. Q4 earnings shot up 550%, with a 180% EPS gain expected in Q1.GrubHub leads in online/mobile food ordering, but it's a fragmented, largely untapped market. Online restaurant and business review site Yelp (YELP) recently announced a deal for GrubHub rival Eat24.GrubHub shares leapt 6.2% on Feb. 5 on those Q4 results. After a forming a handle, GrubHub broke out on Feb. 25. Shares reversed on Thursday, closing just below the 41.85 buy point, but nudged back above that level with a 0.6% advance Friday. The stock peaked at 45.80 on Aug. 13.Vipshop Is No AlibabaVipshop Holdings (VIPS) is leading Chinese e-commerce stock, specializing in flash sales. Last quarter earnings rose 140%, with revenue doubling once again. Analysts expect an 83% gain in the current quarter.While it's a relative minnow to the Alibaba (BABA) whale, Vipshop has been delivering faster growth — and the stock reflects that. Vipshop had a couple of breakout attempts in recent months that quickly fizzed, but broke out on Feb. 17 to a new high, soaring 15.2% on its latest earnings. Shares have moved sideways since then, but fell 3.6% on Friday.(Meanwhile, Alibaba stock has been in a downtrend since peaking at 120 on Nov. 13. The stock tumbled following its last earnings report and has continued to slide, hitting a record closing low last week.)LinkedIn Stock Setting Up AgainLinkedIn (LNKD) is the leading social network for professionals. It's become a go-to site for people looking for jobs — and for companies looking for skilled workers. Earnings rose 56% in the latest quarter on 44% revenue growth, with a 47% EPS forecast for the current Q1.LinkedIn shares gapped up 10.7% on Feb. 6 to a record high following its latest earnings report. That cleared a resistance area going back to early September. Shares have moved sideways in the last few weeks, forming a 3-weeks-tight pattern.Aruba Soars On Earnings, HP BuzzAruba Networks (ARUN) provides WiFi access points and controllers, with a variety of customers that includes Google (GOOGL), Microsoft (MSFT) and Starbucks (SBUX). Aruba late Thursday reported a 67% EPS gain and offered bullish guidance. Analysts expect a 35% increase this quarter, but that may not fully reflect the new outlook. Aruba was mum on reports earlier in the week that Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) might be interested in buying the company.The combination of the strong earnings report and buyout buzz said Aruba's stock soaring 34.7% last week to its best level since April 2013.Facebook Costs Sap Earnings GrowthFacebook (FB) is the dominant social network worldwide, with 1.39 billion monthly active users at the end of last year. Facebook has done a good job adding and monetizing mobile users, with mobile advertising accounting for 69% of ad revenue in Q4. Facebook earnings rose 69% in Q4 on a 49% revenue gain. Expenses shot up 87%, with R&D; costs more than doubling. Expenses are expected to climb 70% in 2015. That will curb earnings growth, with profit seen rising just 18% in Q1 and 12% for the year.Facebook shares hit a record high on Oct. 12. After forming a shallow cup base, the stock briefly peaked out to a new high on Dec. 22. But the next day shares retreated, consolidating again. Shares have moved sideways since the Jan. 28 earnings report. Last week the stock neared a new peak, but fell 1.8% on Friday.Follow Ed Carson on Twitter: @IBD_ECarson.Related:IBD 50 Stocks Outperform; Several Setups EmergeMeet IBD's 4 A Stocks With Rising Earnings Estimates.
Stock futures ladled out moderate losses ahead of Friday's open, as an uptick in May producer prices added to the inflation pressure on the Federal Reserve.
Dow futures slipped 39.4 points below fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures dropped 15.3 points and S&P 500 futures were down 5.4 points.

The stock market today heads into Friday with the Nasdaq up 0.3% this week and the S&P 500 ahead 0.8%. The Nasdaq continued to find support at its 50-day moving average. The S&P 500 slipped below that level late last week, but retook support on Wednesday. A significant change in the eurozone's debt standoff with Greece, or clarity regarding a possible rate increase by the Federal Reserve, could help urge indexes out of their months-long limits. But until the market challenges the high or lows of its recent range, investors must stay prepared for a shift in either direction.

In economic news, prices paid to producers rose 0.5% in May, the Labor Department reported, the largest increase since at least December. The gain reversed April's 0.4% decline, and it topped analyst expectations for a 0.4% increase. The core Producer Price Index, minus energy and food, edged up 0.1% vs. a 0.2% slip in April and in line with expectations.
The University of Michigan is slated to release its initial June consumer sentiment estimate at 10 a.m. ET.

Stock action showedTwitter (TWTR) perking up 3% after announcing Chief Executive Dick Costolo will step down July 1. Twitter co-founder and Chairman Jack Dorsey will serve as interim CEO during a search for a new CEO. Dorsey said he would take no compensation for the position until later in the year. The stock has been unable to exit a consolidation begun shortly after its November 2013 IPO. It ended Thursday 52% below its Dec. 27 high.

Connecticut-based biotech Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) dropped more than 2% in premarket action. The stock has been in a deepening consolidation since December and has been struggling to regain its 10-week moving average since early May.

Among IBD 50 stocks, Synaptics (SYNA) rose 2% before the open. The company announced Thursday it had reached a milestone, with shipments of fingerprint sensors now topping 200 million units. The sensors are used in smartphones, tablets and notebook computers. The stock has been hovering just below a June 3 high, ending Thursday almost 7% above a 91.33 buy point.

Overseas, markets across Asia ended higher, led by a 1.4% jump by Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index. The Shanghai Composite rose 0.9% to end the week up 2.8%. The Hang Seng ended up a fraction for the week. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 rose 0.1% Friday to end the week effectively flat.
Europe's top indexes were also tracking toward flat finishes for the week, with the FTSE 100 in London, Frankfurt's DAX and the CAC-40 in Paris all showing moderate losses near midday.

The dollar continued to gain ground, keeping downward pressure on stocks and commodity prices. Oil and gold traded lower, with West Texas Intermediate futures holding just above $60 per barrel and the August gold contract trading at $1,179.20 an ounce. For the week, oil was up not quite 2%. The bulls failed to mount a counter-attack to Tuesday's sell-off, and stocks finished mildly lower Wednesday in light trading. The Nasdaq fell less than 0.1%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average declined 0.3% in the stock market today. Volume on both exchanges was lighter than Monday, according to preliminary data.
Volkswagen (VLKAY) jumped nearly 7% as its board accepted the resignation of CEO Martin Winterkorn in the wake of a scandal over cheating on emissions tests. The stock is still down 25% this week.

Among IBD 50 stocks, 36 were higher and 14 were lower. The top performer was AMN Healthcare Services (AHS), up more than 3% to a new high. The company, which supplies health care facilities with doctors and nurses, announced the acquisition of First String Healthcare.
Egg Producer Cal-Maine Foods (CALM), another IBD 50 name, rose nearly 3%. It's building the right side of a base.
Another provider of nurses and doctors, Cross Country Healthcare (CCRN), rose nearly 4% in above-average volume to a new high.

Synchronoss Technologies (SNCR) fell 11% in monster volume. An analyst reportedly said the company might lose Verizon (VZ) as a cloud customer. Stocks were mixed near Friday's midpoint amid a barrage of earnings reports and mixed economic data.
Thanks to strength in Internet and software stocks, the Nasdaq rose 0.3%. But the Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 were off 0.2% each. Volume was tracking lower across the board.

Cloud storage company Box (BOX) came pubic with a bang. Late Thursday, the company sold 12.5 million shares at 14 each or above the expected range of 11 to 13. Shares opened at 20.20 in the stock market today and ran as high as 24.73. It has since settled to about 23.41. Box was recently featured in New Issue America.

Starbucks (SBUX) gapped up and rallied 6% to a new high in reaction to late Thursday's fiscal Q1 results. The stock opened above an 84.30 buy point from a flat base. Oppenheimer boosted the stock's price target to 95 from 86.

Michaels (MIK) gapped up and rallied 5% in fast trade. Late Thursday, the arts and crafts supplies retailer priced an offering of 18.8 million shares at 23.52 each or right at Thursday's closing price. On Tuesday, Michaels guided fiscal Q4 sales above views.
UPS (UPS) gapped below its 50-day line and plunged 10% after giving a downbeat outlook . The stock is close to potential support at its 200-day moving average.

Rival FedEx (FDX) maintained its outlook for its fiscal 2015 ending in May. Stocks opened battling near break-even points Friday, unsettled by mixed earnings reports and wavering oil prices.
The Nasdaq held out a 0.2% gain. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each slipped 0.2%.
Trade was soft, down 12% on the Nasdaq and 6% lower on the NYSE compared with volume at the same time Thursday.

The stock market today borrowed premarket strength from Europe's advancing stocks and from an upward blip in oil prices. But oil fell back into mild losses, and a spray of blue chip earnings reports helped put a dent in early trade.
Economic news was also lukewarm. A preliminary U.S. manufacturing index from researcher Markit showed no change in January, at 53.7. That disappointed expectations for an uptick to 54.

Existing-home sales data were mixed, rising to an annualized rate of 5.04 million for December, according to the National Association of Realtors. That beat November's 4.92 sales pace, but stopped just short of economist projections for 5.05 million.
The Conference Board reported its Leading Economic Indicators Index eased to 0.5%, down from 0.6% in November. Analyst had estimated a dip to 0.4%.
In stocks, McDonald's (MCD) and General Electric (GE) edged higher, Kimberly Clark (KMB) and Rockwell Collins (COL) fell after reporting quarterly results.
Starbucks (SBUX) was a big early winner, up 6% to new highs after a strong Q4 report. The strong volume gain also broke the stock out past buy points at 83.43 and 84.30.
The IBD 50 list opened mixed, half up, half down.
Ulta Beauty (ULTA) rose 2% to top the list. The move sent shares past a 134.60 buy point in a seven-week flat base.
Ambarella (AMBA) dropped 2%, the widest loss on the list. The stock remains extended, trading below a Jan. 13 high and its 10-week line of support.

United Parcel Service (UPS) collapsed 10%. The freight heavyweight offered preliminary fourth-quarter earnings guidance far below consensus views. The gap-down loss pulled shares away from a new high, sending the stock through its 10-week moving average in heavy trade.

Chip sector stocks were taking some hard hits, led by KLA-Tencor (KLAC), which fell 7%. The chip equipment maker reported stronger-than-expected fiscal second-quarter sales and earnings. But management guided Q3 revenue and earnings well below consensus. The European Union's initial finding Friday that Amazon's tax deal with Luxembourg amounted to illegal state aid may curb hidden deals, but nations will continue to use tax deals to compete for companies, experts said.

The increasing scrutiny of multinationals looking to reduce corporate taxes — and the European nations willing to help — is not going away. Other EU tax investigations involved alleged illegal state aid to Apple (AAPL) by Ireland and to Starbucks (SBUX) by Dutch tax authorities.
The global financial crisis and Europe's bailouts and record unemployment have made it politically untenable for EU officials to quietly green-light tax deals to huge corporations.
"You can't do these kind of hidden deals anymore," said Jacob Funk Kirkegaard, a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics.

The European Commission has no power to set member nations' tax policies, but the EU's executive arm does have some policing authority if it deems that some tax laws give unfair advantage to one member nation at the expense of others.
EU members has agreed to more transparency in their tax deals with multinationals, making backroom pacts less likely.
Bad PR Vs. 'Clever Lawyers'
"Will there be no more of these deals? Not likely," said David Kautter, a partner at McGladrey, a Chicago-based tax consultant.

Multinational corporations are likely to proceed with greater caution when negotiating EU tax deals. "They could face very bad press that could hurt their businesses," Kirkegaard said. "There's nothing that very clever tax lawyers can do about that."

The Amazon (AMZN) deal let the e-commerce giant's European operations avoid tax liability elsewhere on the Continent via a tax-free unit in Luxembourg, population 543,000, just south of Belgium. The EU, which launched the probe last year, said the 2003 tax deal was a "cosmetic arrangement," not an operational need, that gave Amazon an unfair advantage over rivals.

Amazon has denied special tax treatment and could opt to fight through the European Court of Justice, which likely would take years. Luxembourg has a corporate tax rate a bit less than 30%, but allegedly let Amazon save on its taxes administratively.
If the EU's decision becomes final, Luxembourg may have to collect back taxes from Amazon.

The inconvenience and embarrassment may be more significant than the back taxes Amazon might owe, perhaps only tens of millions of dollars, observers said. Amazon paid an average $293 million annually in income taxes from 2011 to 2013 and managed an annual average after-tax $288 million profit in those years.
U.S. No. 1. In Tax Rates
The crackdown on sweetheart tax deals could cause some political discomfort for new EC President Jean-Claude Juncker.
His previous jobs include an 18-year tenure as Luxembourg's prime minister, when that nation, some said, became a better tax haven.

In a larger sense, multinational businesses and nations are in awkward positions. Many governments have pledged fair tax policies that won't harm their neighbors, but at the same time compete for the jobs and economic growth that multinationals supply. One way to attract such companies is through favorable taxes.

To put things in perspective, when the U.S. lowered its federal corporate tax rate to 35% (an average of 39.6% with state and local rates) in 1986, that rate was among the lowest in the developed world. Today, it's the highest. GOP lawmakers and President Obama have both called for a lower tax rate — which would help end the incentive for "tax inversion" takeover deals — but differ on key details.

Some have argued that Ireland's 12.5% corporate tax rate is unfair. But Ireland and others say this reflects healthy competition that encourages governments to adopt tax and regulatory policies that are attractive to business.The European Union's initial finding Friday that Amazon's tax deal with Luxembourg amounted to illegal state aid may curb hidden deals, but nations will continue to use tax deals to compete for companies, experts said.The increasing scrutiny of multinationals looking to reduce corporate taxes — and the European nations willing to help — is not going away. "There's nothing that very clever tax lawyers can do about that."The Amazon (AMZN) deal let the e-commerce giant's European operations avoid tax liability elsewhere on the Continent via a tax-free unit in Luxembourg, population 543,000, just south of Belgium. Stocks were firmly lower near Monday's midpoint after an early rally collapsed. A downside reversal in oil is weighing on equities. Brent crude had been bouncing back after hitting a 5-1/2 year low Friday.

The Nasdaq dropped 0.9% after reversing a 0.8% gain. But it's close to potential support at its 50-day line. The S&P 500, which was also up as much as 0.8%, lost 0.6%. It fell below the psychological 2000 level and the 50-day moving average. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average was off by 0.5%. Volume was running mixed in the stock market today. Nasdaq trade was running higher and NYSE turnover was tracking lower.
Some leaders were getting whacked.

Habit Restaurants (HABT) dropped 11% after staging a huge downside reversal. It slumped more than 10% below a 40.35 buy point from an IPO base. Losses should always be cut at 7% or 8%. The stock was on the receiving end of some lukewarm analyst actions. Stifel Nicolaus and Robert W. Baird started coverage at hold and neutral, respectively. Raymond James also initiated coverage with a market perform rating.

Acadia Healthcare (ACHC) fell nearly 4% in fast trade. At Monday's low, the stock fell more than 7% below a 63.96 buy point from a pattern that could be three-weeks-tight or four-weeks-tight formation.
Starbucks (SBUX) fell nearly 3% in heavy trading. But it's still 4% past a 77.77 buy point from a cup-with-handle base cleared Nov. 7.

Leaders up in volume were few, but Cirrus Logic (CRUS) pushed its gain to nearly 20. Barclays upgraded the chip designer to overweight from an underweight rating and upped its price target to 28 from 18. Stocks pecked out modest early gains Thursday as investors took in a raft of earnings reports, housing and unemployment data and a highly anticipated policy announcement from the European Central Bank.

The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 each added 0.4%. The Dow Jones industrial average checked in with a 0.3% gain. Volume rose 10% on the Nasdaq and was 5% higher on the NYSE compared with trade at the same time Wednesday.

The stock market today received an early lift from the European Central Bank, which upgraded its monetary stimulus efforts to include heftier-than-anticipated asset purchases of nearly $70 billion per month. Purchases of government and European institutional bonds will begin in March and run for 18 months, ECB President Mario Draghi said. The bank also held its primary lending rate unchanged at a record-low 0.05%.

In U.S. economic news, the Federal Housing Finance Agency said its Housing Price Index gained 0.8% in November. That was a step above October's 0.6% gain and stronger than the 0.3% gain projected by economists.

In stocks, earnings reports helped place financial and chip sector plays under early pressure. American Express (AXP) and Discover Financial Services (DFS) dived 4% and 8%, respectively, after delivering quarterly results late Wednesday. SanDisk (SNDK) shed 6% and Xilinx (XLNX) dropped 10%, also following reports made after Wednesday's close.

Southwest Airlines (LUV) leapt 5% after a healthy Q4 report. That bumped the stock to a new high and out of buying range on its first test of 10-week support since clearing a short cup base in November.
EBay (EBAY) climbed 4% after announcing the possible spinoff of its eBay Marketing unit. The gain lifted shares back to their 10-week moving average in the fifth week of a shallow consolidation.

Switzerland-based Logitech International (LOGI) popped 7%. The mouse, keyboard and joystick maker reported a fiscal third-quarter earnings gain vs. forecasts for an 8% loss. The gain drove shares just above a 15.15 buy point in a six-week cup base.

On the downside, F5 Networks (FFIV) crumbled 11%. The developer of network optimization software reported after Wednesday's close its fiscal first-quarter earnings beat, with revenue meeting analyst consensus projections. But management gave Q2 earnings guidance below expectations and said the company saw "a marked decrease in the number of deals greater than $1 million" during the quarter. The loss drove shares below their 40-week moving average, but stopped short of an October low.

Here's a look at three of the top companies reporting quarterly earnings on Thursday.
Alaska Air (ALK) reports before the open. Shares have been hitting new highs on cheaper fuel and a stronger U.S. economy.
United Continental (UAL) and Southwest Airlines (LUV) also report earnings on Thursday.
Starbucks (SBUX) reports after the close. Mobile payments, which account for more than 16% of the coffee house's U.S. revenue, are expected to have a big impact.

Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) also reports after the close. It's one of Apple's (AAPL) key suppliers, and demand for its chips is expected to grow with the continued demand for Apple's new iPhone 6 product line.

Stocks hit fresh session highs late Thursday and were on track for a fourth straight gain.

Helped by Internet and computer hardware stocks, the Nasdaq rallied 1.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 were each up 1%. Volume was tracking modestly higher on both major exchanges in the stock market today

Tata Motors (TTM) stretched its gain to 3%. Earlier, the stock cleared a 48.28 buy point in a double-bottom base in heavy trading. The Indian carmaker has a Composite Rating of 83, the highest in the Auto Manufacturers group. Tata was mentioned in International Leaders earlier this month.

Under Armour (UA) rallied 3% and regained its 50-day line in fast trade. The stock is in a flat base within a larger pattern. Telsey Advisory Group upgraded shares to outperform from market perform Wednesday.

On the downside, Microsemi (MSCC) reversed and fell 2% ahead of its fiscal Q1 earnings after the close. The chipmaker is expected to earn 65 cents a share, up 41% from a year ago. That would mark a second straight quarter of accelerating growth. Microsemi is working on a potential base.

Starbucks customers are a loyal bunch — loyal enough to protest the departure of their beloved eggnog latte, prompting the coffee chain to revive the seasonal favorite, and loyal enough to make the company the No. 1 most-expensed restaurant for business travelers.
But would they be loyal enough to someday use a Starbucks (SBUX)-brand mobile payment system outside its coffeehouses instead of Apple (AAPL) Pay?

Apple may have been able to boast 1 million sign-ups for its e-payment service within three days of launching, but the java giant has long been sitting on an impressive database of coffee lovers — and their credit card information — with its mobile app.

Starbucks would join an increasingly competitive field, which includes Google (GOOGL) Wallet, eBay's (EBAY) soon-to-be-spun-off PayPal and CurrentC, a system backed by retail giants like CVS Health (CVS), Rite Aid (RAD) and Wal-Mart (WMT) and set to roll out next year.

Of the 7 million weekly transactions that take place at Starbucks registers, 16% are made from a mobile device, CEO Howard Schultz said last month in an earnings call, during which he claimed Starbucks had nabbed nine-tenths of the $1.3 billion mobile payment market last year.

"What they're doing with mobile pay is revolutionary, in my opinion," Wedbush Securities analyst Nick Setyan told IBD. "Ninety percent of mobile pay in the U.S. takes place at Starbucks locations. That's a testament to how far ahead of everyone else they are."
And Schultz has hinted that a stand-alone e-payment system may be on the horizon.
Starbucks had "cracked the code" at connecting mobile payments to customer loyalty, he said during the call.

"(W)e are now receiving great interest in partnerships from mobile payment companies who see the value of our rewards program and the mobile payment behavior we established," he said, adding that the company would be cautious in choosing partners and how it moves forward.
"But I can assure you that Starbucks will have a major role to play, both inside and outside of our stores as the nascent mobile payment industry evolves."

While no definitive details are out, the move wouldn't be a complete surprise to some, given Starbucks' acquisition of Evolution Fresh, launch of Evolution Fresh bars and trail mix, and purchase of the La Boulange bakery chain.

"If you look at what Starbucks has been doing the past five years, one thing becomes clear: It wants to control its own destiny and own its ecosystem," said Belus Capital Advisors' Brian Sozzi via email.

When asked if the coffee chain could give the tech behemoth a run for its money, he replied: "Yes, indeed. Starbucks has become our daily habit, something we constantly think about ... almost as much as using our iPhone."
Not A 'Reasonable Investment'

Yet creating an Apple Pay-like system from the ground up would be a different beast than simply connecting rewards accounts to credit cards, and instead would involve banks and plenty of compliance hoops to jump through.

"To develop a stand-alone payment system is. . . not a reasonable investment" on Starbucks' part, said analyst Setyan, who said the only benefit would be lower transaction-processing costs. Taking it to the mainstream would be a "big, big, big process.
"From my point of view, I just think it's not the best use of their time," he said.

Wedbush Securities' Gil Luria agrees. While he also called mobile order-and-pay "a revolutionary step," he was less optimistic about the idea of a stand-alone system, calling it an "uphill battle" and questioning why issuers and banks would want to cut the coffee chain in on the action.
And consumers?
"Just because they want to use a Starbucks card at Starbucks doesn't mean they want to use a Starbucks card anywhere else," he said.
Siren Song

But those skeptical of the green mermaid's devotees should also keep in mind that her siren song has made consumers do crazier things than sign up for an e-pay service. Starbucks memorably sold all 1,000 of its $450 rose-gold metal gift cards within minutes last year, and may very well sell out again with this season's $110 Swarovski-studded tumblers and $200 sterling silver cards — which notably only come loaded with $50.
In the meantime, Starbucks is keeping customers caffeinated with order-ahead and delivery pilot programs in a digital push that's more about e-commerce than coffee.

Starbucks' mobile order-and-pay service launches in Portland in December, allowing customers to order their Venti mochas and Grande Fizzios by smartphone and pick them up in stores. It will expand nationwide next year.

"Going forward, what they're doing with mobile order-and-pay should give them a leg up," said Wedbush's Setyan, noting in an Oct. 31 report that he sees order-and-pay and the delivery pilot as "potential game changers in FY15."

The order-ahead program could also help streamline in-store foot traffic as the company expands its food and drink selection to items like wine and tapas-style plates in select cities. Sozzi thinks mobile pay and deliveries could ease pressure on lines as Starbucks' menu gets larger and more complex.

With more purchases moving online, CEO Schultz has made clear his concerns about a "seismic shift in consumer behavior." His answer to that appears to be a delivery program in certain markets in the latter half of 2015.
"Imagine the ability to create a standing order of Starbucks delivered, hot or iced, to your desk daily. That's our version of e-commerce on steroids," said Schultz during the call.

Of course, there are plenty of potential obstacles involved with delivery, including quality control — how well will that latte survive a cross-town trip in the dead of winter? — and the resources and manpower involved in rolling out such an ambitious undertaking.
"It's very early days at this, but we are moving ahead — full steam ahead," said Starbucks Global Chief Strategy Officer Matt Ryan during the call. "The pilots are coming soon."
The company said capital expenditures will be "somewhat higher" at $1.4 billion for fiscal 2015 as it invests more in the mobile order-and-pay program, store growth and evening stores.
Analysts don't seem concerned.

"If anyone can do it, it's Starbucks," said Wedbush's Setyan.Starbucks customers are a loyal bunch — loyal enough to protest the departure of their beloved eggnog latte, prompting the coffee chain to revive the seasonal favorite, and loyal enough to make the company the No. 1 most-expensed restaurant for business travelers.But would they be loyal enough to someday use a Starbucks (SBUX)-brand mobile payment system outside its coffeehouses instead of Apple (AAPL) Pay?Apple may have been able to boast 1 million sign-ups for its e-payment service within three days of launching, but the java giant has long been sitting on an impressive database of coffee lovers — and their credit card information — with its mobile app.Starbucks would join an increasingly competitive field, which includes Google (GOOGL) Wallet, eBay's (EBAY) soon-to-be-spun-off PayPal and CurrentC, a system backed by retail giants like CVS Health (CVS), Rite Aid (RAD) and Wal-Mart (WMT) and set to roll out next year.Of the 7 million weekly transactions that take place at Starbucks registers, 16% are made from a mobile device, CEO Howard Schultz said last month in an earnings call, during which he claimed Starbucks had nabbed nine-tenths of the $1.3 billion mobile payment market last year."What they're doing with mobile pay is revolutionary, in my opinion," Wedbush Securities analyst Nick Setyan told IBD. Enterprise wireless up-and-comer Aruba Networks beat Wall Street revenue and profit views late Thursday as fiscal first-quarter revenue jumped 29% over the prior year to $207.8 million and earnings rose 62.5% to 26 cents per share.

Revenue came in nearly $5 million more than analysts had expected. Earnings beat by a penny. But Aruba (ARUN) sees Q2 EPS of 26-27 cents on revenue of $208 million-$212 million. Analysts see EPS of 27 cents on revenue of $211.6 million.
Shares fell more than 7% in after-hours trading. Shares had closed up 1.25% Thursday.
Aruba sells Wi-Fi access points and the controllers that manage them to thousands of customers in government, education, health care and other markets.
Customers such as Google (GOOGL) and Microsoft (MSFT) use them to enable Wi-Fi connectivity at their offices, Starbucks (SBUX) at their cafes.
Adoption of a new, faster Wi-Fi networking standard known as 802.11ac helped the company notch its third straight quarter of steep earnings growth in Q1.
"Adoption of 802.11ac technology continued to drive growth in many of our verticals, including federal government, retail and enterprise," said CEO Dominic Orr in an earnings statement.
He added that the company is seeing its focus on penetrating the fast-growing small- to mid-sized enterprise market paying off.
Doubts About Sustainability
To boost the bottom line, Aruba had announced in the last quarter that it would cut staff by 4%, or 70 employees, and relocate another 4% to lower-cost locations.
"Our focus on profitable growth is paying off," Orr said in Thursday's post-earnings conference call.

"They had a really good July quarter and a good October quarter. Just when you think there's a winning streak, they came out with guidance that was a bit disappointing," said analyst Jason Ader of William Blair. "They are running into an expectations challenge. The margins are expanding, but the revenue (guidance) is a little light — just enough to question the sustainability."
Though most of its business is in the U.S., Aruba sells overseas as well. And in the post-earnings conference call, management cited challenging sales in Asia.
But operating margin of 21.8% was well up from last year's 16.2%, prompting analyst Mark Sue of RBC Capital Markets to note that Aruba is able to contain spending while growing the top line.
"The quarter was pretty strong, considering the environment was a little mixed," he said.
Taking Share From Cisco

Sunnyvale, Calif.-based Aruba says it has been taking share in the $5 billion enterprise Wi-Fi networking market from larger rival Cisco Systems (CSCO), as evidenced by its much faster revenue growth than Cisco's over the last year.
"The Wi-Fi market is growing in the mid-teens. Aruba is growing faster," Sue said.
Aruba also competes with smaller companies such as Aerohive Networks (HIVE) and Ruckus Wireless (RKUS).
Earlier this month, Aruba said that it would expand into indoor location-specific mobile marketing, using Aruba Beacons, a Bluetooth sensor technology.

Marketing departments in retail, hospitality, sports venues and others can use Aruba's technology to relay promotions, product location and other information in real time to customers' Android and iPhone devices.Enterprise wireless up-and-comer Aruba Networks beat Wall Street revenue and profit views late Thursday as fiscal first-quarter revenue jumped 29% over the prior year to $207.8 million and earnings rose 62.5% to 26 cents per share.Revenue came in nearly $5 million more than analysts had expected. Stocks ended higher Thursday, as some leading stocks moved sharply after the close on earnings reports.

The Nasdaq rose 0.4% and the S&P 500 rose 0.6%, with volume lighter on both exchanges, according to preliminary data. The Dow Jones industrial average led the way, up 1.3%, thanks to component Visa (V), which was up 10% on the back of a better-than-expected earnings report.

After hours in the stock market today, GoPro (GPRO) was up after reporting EPS of 12 cents a share, four cents better than analysts' forecasts. Sales were $280 million vs. estimates of $265.56 million. If the momentum continues into Friday, the stock could recover above its 50-day moving average, which it dipped below on Monday.

LinkedIn (LNKD) was down after hours despite reporting better-than-expected Q3 numbers, although guidance was light. It reported revenue of $568 million vs. estimates of $557 million. EPS was 52 cents against estimates of 47 cents. But the company forecast $600 million to $605 million in revenue for the current quarter. Analysts were expecting $612 million.
Starbucks (SBUX) was down sharply after hours. It reported earnings in line with estimates, but Q1 EPS guidance of 79 cents to 81 cents. Analysts were expecting 83 cents.

GoPro, LinkedIn, FleetCor Technologies and Starbucks are four notable companies that are set to report earnings after the close on Thursday. Here's a look at what analysts expect.

The action camera maker is expected to earn 8 cents a share on revenue of $266 million. Q2 was GoPro's (GPRO) first quarter as a publicly traded company, and it earned 10 cents a share on revenue of $245 million, topping expectations for both measures.

Shares are up about 180% since the company went public at 24 in June. But GoPro is more than 30% off its all-time high of 98.46 on Oct. 7 and down 3.8% in the stock market today heading into its quarterly results. GoPro is currently on Leaderboard's Leaders List.
LinkedIn (LNKD) is projected to earn 47 cents a share, a 21% gain from last year. Revenue is seen climbing 42% to $557 million.
The professional social network is a former Leaderboard stock that has been building a base for more than a year. Earnings in 2015 are expected to rebound 47%. Shares dipped 1.4%.
FleetCor Technologies (FLT) is projected to see a 24% boost in earnings to $1.34 a share. Revenue is expected to jump 26% to $283 million.
The provider of fuel-payment cards for trucking and other fleet operators is on the IBD 50 list of top stocks. Shares dipped 0.1%.
Starbucks (SBUX) is expected to earn 74 cents a share, a 17% rise from last year in its 2014 fiscal Q4. Revenue is seen growing 12% to $4.2 billion.

The coffeehouse chain announced in late September that it would buy the remaining 60.5% of Starbucks Coffee Japan that it didn't already own. Starbucks said it expects the deal to be "slightly accretive" to its fiscal 2015 results. Shares were little changed as of midday Thursday.
Make sure to watch our video report by IBD TV's Alissa Williams.

Starbucks' (SBUX) new "Mobile Order and Pay" service could make its already successful digital wallet even more attractive for customers, slash in-store waiting times, and increase revenue via mobile payments, says RBC Capital in a report.
The coffee behemoth started a trial program of "Mobile Order and Pay" in Portland, Ore., on Wednesday. The company plans to expand the program throughout the U.S. and London in 2015.

Starbucks' mobile wallet, a barcode-based payment app, enables customers to pay with a swipe of their mobile phone. The mobile app has more than 12 million users. Starbucks garners more than 16% of U.S. revenue from mobile payments. Customers earn free coffee and other perks through a loyalty program.

The "Mobile Order and Pay" feature allows customers to place an order on their mobile phone and schedule a pick up. The feature requires that users opt-in for location-based technology to identify the nearest location accepting "Mobile Order and Pay."

"We believe that mobile order and pay, combined with the continued adoption of the company loyalty program, will be a consistent driver of growth going forward," RBC Capital analyst David Palmer said in a report. "Once deployed, the feature should drive both transaction and check growth by reducing the bottleneck at the point-of-sale and driving greater frequency by decreasing the total time spent by consumers to make a purchase. These consumer-facing benefits should encourage greater adoption of the Starbucks card, which traditionally drives frequency, average check size, and enables the company to engage in one-to-one marketing."
"Mobile Order and Pay will drive additional traffic by reducing the line in-store and preventing lost sales from consumers discouraged by the line," Palmer added.
Starbucks has been exploring whether to extend its mobile wallet program to third-party merchants who want to share in the rewards program, as IBD reported.

Apple (AAPL) unveiled its mobile payment system in late September as part of the iPhone 6 launch. Apple Pay joined a crowded field, including eBay's (EBAY) soon-to-be-spun-off PayPal and MCX, a retail consortium backed by Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) and Best Buy (BBY). Apple has been working closely with credit card networks, giving it an edge over Google's (GOOGL) mobile payment system and other early entrants.
